prompt: Discuss the limitations and implications of accounting for intangible assets such as goodwill, patents, and brands.

criteria.name: Understanding of Intangible Assets
criteria.description: Demonstrates knowledge of different types of intangible assets and their characteristics.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Clearly defines and differentiates types of intangible assets with relevant examples.
performance_descriptors.good: Defines major intangible assets with some examples.
performance_descriptors.average: Mentions intangible assets with limited detail.
performance_descriptors.poor: Fails to explain or misidentifies intangible assets.

criteria.name: Application of Accounting Standards
criteria.description: Applies IFRS standards (e.g., IAS 38, IFRS 3) in discussing recognition and valuation.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Accurately applies relevant IFRS standards and explains their impact.
performance_descriptors.good: Applies at least one standard with minor errors or omissions.
performance_descriptors.average: Mentions standards but lacks clarity or connection.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Minimal or unclear use of standards.

criteria.name: Evaluation of Measurement and Impairment Challenges
criteria.description: Evaluates the complexity of valuing intangibles and conducting impairment testing.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Insightful evaluation of valuation issues, impairment, and risk of misstatement.
performance_descriptors.good: Explains measurement challenges with moderate detail.
performance_descriptors.average: Touches on challenges without much analysis.
performance_descriptors.poor: No discussion of valuation or impairment issues.

criteria.name: Implications for Financial Reporting and M&A
criteria.description: Analyzes how intangible assets affect mergers, acquisitions, and reported financials.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Thoroughly evaluates how intangible assets influence business valuation and reporting outcomes.
performance_descriptors.good: Explains the implications with moderate analysis.
performance_descriptors.average: Mentions relevance in M&A or reporting with limited depth.
performance_descriptors.poor: Fails to link intangible assets to M&A or reporting.

criteria.name: Structure and Academic Style
criteria.description: Presents content in a formal academic tone with logical structure.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Highly structured essay with formal tone and strong flow.
performance_descriptors.good: Mostly well-organized and academic in tone.
performance_descriptors.average: Some structure; inconsistencies in style or clarity.

key_points: Define intangible assets and distinguish internally generated vs. acquired assets.
Explain IAS 38 and IFRS 3 regarding recognition and post-acquisition treatment of intangibles.
Describe impairment testing methods, especially for goodwill.
Discuss how intangible assets affect valuation during M&A activities.
Evaluate challenges in aligning economic value with reported book value.
llm_questions: What are intangible assets and how are they classified in accounting?
What do IAS 38 and IFRS 3 say about the recognition of goodwill and patents?
How is impairment testing done for intangible assets like goodwill?
How do intangible assets affect the valuation of companies during mergers and acquisitions?
What are the challenges of measuring the true economic value of intangible assets?
Can you explain the difference between book value and market value for brands or patents?
Why is it difficult to account for internally generated intangible assets?
